      id: GO:0005768
      label: endosome
    evidence_type: IDA
    original_reference_id: PMID:16554368
    review:
      summary: EGFR localizes to endosomes following ligand-induced 
        internalization. EGFR continues signaling from early endosomes and is 
        subsequently sorted for recycling or lysosomal degradation.
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: Endosomal localization is part of normal EGFR trafficking and 
        signaling. EGFR signals from endosomes and trafficking modulates signal 
        duration.
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:16554368
          supporting_text: Mar 22. The ESCRT-III subunit hVps24 is required for 
            degradation but not silencing of the epidermal growth factor 
            receptor.

    evidence_type: IPI
    original_reference_id: PMID:9852145
    review:
      summary: Generic 'protein binding' term provides no specific information 
        about EGFR molecular function.
      action: REMOVE
      reason: Per GO curation guidelines, 'protein binding' is uninformative and
        should be replaced with more specific binding terms. EGFR interacts with
        many proteins including ligands (EGF), dimerization partners (ERBB2-4), 
        adaptors (GRB2, SHC), and signaling molecules, but this generic term 
        does not capture any specific binding activity.
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:9852145
          supporting_text: Interaction of ZPR1 with translation elongation 
            factor-1alpha in proliferating cells.
  - term:
      id: GO:0043235
      label: receptor complex
    evidence_type: IDA
    original_reference_id: PMID:23382219
    review:
      summary: EGFR forms homo- and heterodimeric receptor complexes upon ligand
        binding, which is required for kinase activation.
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: EGFR dimerization into receptor complexes is essential for signal 
        transduction. EGFR forms homodimers and heterodimers with ERBB2, ERBB3, 
        ERBB4.
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:23382219
          supporting_text: Structural basis for endosomal trafficking of diverse
            transmembrane cargos by PX-FERM proteins.
  - term:
      id: GO:0007611
      label: learning or memory
    evidence_type: ISS
    original_reference_id: GO_REF:0000024
    review:
      summary: EGFR signaling may influence learning and memory processes.
      action: KEEP_AS_NON_CORE
      reason: High-level behavioral phenotype, represents very downstream 
        effects.
  - term:
      id: GO:0071364
      label: cellular response to epidermal growth factor stimulus
    evidence_type: ISS
    original_reference_id: GO_REF:0000024
    review:
      summary: EGFR mediates cellular responses to EGF.
      action: KEEP_AS_NON_CORE
      reason: This describes the cellular response, not the core receptor 
        function.
  - term:
      id: GO:0001934
      label: positive regulation of protein phosphorylation
    evidence_type: IDA
    original_reference_id: PMID:20551055
    review:
      summary: EGFR promotes protein phosphorylation through its kinase activity
        and downstream signaling.
      action: KEEP_AS_NON_CORE
      reason: This is a general downstream effect of EGFR signaling.
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:20551055
          supporting_text: Epub 2010 Jun 15. Nuclear alternate estrogen receptor
            GPR30 mediates 17beta-estradiol-induced gene expression and 
            migration in breast cancer-associated fibroblasts.
  - term:
      id: GO:0003682
      label: chromatin binding
    evidence_type: IDA
    original_reference_id: PMID:20551055
    review:
      summary: Nuclear EGFR has been reported to bind chromatin and regulate 
        transcription.
      action: KEEP_AS_NON_CORE
      reason: Nuclear EGFR has been described in some contexts, but this is not 
        a core function of EGFR.
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:20551055
          supporting_text: Epub 2010 Jun 15. Nuclear alternate estrogen receptor
            GPR30 mediates 17beta-estradiol-induced gene expression and 
            migration in breast cancer-associated fibroblasts.
  - term:
      id: GO:0005515
      label: protein binding
    evidence_type: IPI
    original_reference_id: PMID:20551055
    review:
      summary: Generic 'protein binding' term provides no specific information 
        about EGFR molecular function.
      action: REMOVE
      reason: Per GO curation guidelines, 'protein binding' is uninformative and
        should be replaced with more specific binding terms. EGFR interacts with
        many proteins including ligands (EGF), dimerization partners (ERBB2-4), 
        adaptors (GRB2, SHC), and signaling molecules, but this generic term 
        does not capture any specific binding activity.
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:20551055
          supporting_text: Epub 2010 Jun 15. Nuclear alternate estrogen receptor
            GPR30 mediates 17beta-estradiol-induced gene expression and 
            migration in breast cancer-associated fibroblasts.
  - term:
      id: GO:0005634
      label: nucleus
    evidence_type: IDA
    original_reference_id: PMID:20551055
    review:
      summary: Nuclear EGFR has been described in certain contexts and may have 
        transcriptional roles.
      action: KEEP_AS_NON_CORE
      reason: Nuclear EGFR is documented but represents a minor, 
        context-dependent localization rather than core EGFR function.
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:20551055
          supporting_text: Epub 2010 Jun 15. Nuclear alternate estrogen receptor
            GPR30 mediates 17beta-estradiol-induced gene expression and 
            migration in breast cancer-associated fibroblasts.
  - term:
      id: GO:0045944
      label: positive regulation of transcription by RNA polymerase II
    evidence_type: IDA
    original_reference_id: PMID:20551055
    review:
      summary: EGFR signaling leads to transcriptional activation of target 
        genes.
      action: KEEP_AS_NON_CORE
      reason: Transcriptional regulation is a downstream effect of EGFR 
        signaling pathways.
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:20551055
          supporting_text: Epub 2010 Jun 15. Nuclear alternate estrogen receptor
            GPR30 mediates 17beta-estradiol-induced gene expression and 
            migration in breast cancer-associated fibroblasts.
  - term:
      id: GO:0070374
      label: positive regulation of ERK1 and ERK2 cascade
    evidence_type: IDA
    original_reference_id: PMID:20551055
    review:
      summary: EGFR positively regulates ERK1/2 cascade through RAS-RAF-MEK-ERK 
        signaling axis.
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: ERK1/2 activation is a core readout of EGFR signaling through the 
        MAPK pathway.
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:20551055
          supporting_text: Epub 2010 Jun 15. Nuclear alternate estrogen receptor
            GPR30 mediates 17beta-estradiol-induced gene expression and 
            migration in breast cancer-associated fibroblasts.
  - term:
      id: GO:0071392
      label: cellular response to estradiol stimulus
    evidence_type: IDA
    original_reference_id: PMID:20551055
    review:
      summary: EGFR can be activated in response to estradiol through crosstalk 
        mechanisms.
      action: KEEP_AS_NON_CORE
      reason: Estradiol response represents crosstalk/secondary activation, not 
        core function.
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:20551055
          supporting_text: Epub 2010 Jun 15. Nuclear alternate estrogen receptor
            GPR30 mediates 17beta-estradiol-induced gene expression and 
            migration in breast cancer-associated fibroblasts.
  - term:
      id: GO:0005886
      label: plasma membrane
    evidence_type: TAS
    original_reference_id: Reactome:R-HSA-1247999
    review:
      summary: EGFR is a transmembrane receptor that localizes to the plasma 
        membrane where it binds extracellular ligands and initiates 
        intracellular signaling.
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: Plasma membrane localization is essential for EGFR function as a 
        cell surface receptor. EGFR resides at the plasma membrane to receive 
        extracellular growth factor signals.

      reason: Plasma membrane localization is essential for EGFR function as a 
        cell surface receptor. EGFR resides at the plasma membrane to receive 
        extracellular growth factor signals.

      id: GO:0005886
      label: plasma membrane
    evidence_type: TAS
    original_reference_id: Reactome:R-HSA-9665408
    review:
      summary: EGFR is a transmembrane receptor that localizes to the plasma 
        membrane where it binds extracellular ligands and initiates 
        intracellular signaling.
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: Plasma membrane localization is essential for EGFR function as a 
        cell surface receptor. EGFR resides at the plasma membrane to receive 
        extracellular growth factor signals.

  - term:
      id: GO:0005515
      label: protein binding
    evidence_type: IPI
    original_reference_id: PMID:19509291
    review:
      summary: Generic 'protein binding' term provides no specific information 
        about EGFR molecular function.
      action: REMOVE
      reason: Per GO curation guidelines, 'protein binding' is uninformative and
        should be replaced with more specific binding terms. EGFR interacts with
        many proteins including ligands (EGF), dimerization partners (ERBB2-4), 
        adaptors (GRB2, SHC), and signaling molecules, but this generic term 
        does not capture any specific binding activity.
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:19509291
          supporting_text: 2009 Jun 9. GAREM, a novel adaptor protein for growth
            factor receptor-bound protein 2, contributes to cellular 
            transformation through the activation of extracellular 
            signal-regulated kinase signaling.

  - term:
      id: GO:0004713
      label: protein tyrosine kinase activity
    evidence_type: IDA
    original_reference_id: PMID:17115032
    review:
      summary: EGFR possesses protein tyrosine kinase activity, phosphorylating 
        itself and downstream substrates upon activation.
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: Protein tyrosine kinase activity is fundamental to EGFR signaling.
        This is the parent term of transmembrane receptor protein tyrosine 
        kinase activity and accurately describes EGFR function.
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:17115032
          supporting_text: Tyrosine phosphorylation controls PCNA function 
            through protein stability.
  - term:
      id: GO:0005006
      label: epidermal growth factor receptor activity

    original_reference_id: PMID:17115032
    review:
      summary: EGFR is the prototypical EGF receptor, binding EGF and related 
        ligands to initiate signaling cascades controlling proliferation, 
        survival, and differentiation.
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: This is the most specific molecular function term for EGFR and is 
        definitionally correct.
      supported_by:

            through protein stability.

      id: GO:0005634
      label: nucleus
    evidence_type: IDA
    original_reference_id: PMID:17115032
    review:
      summary: Nuclear EGFR has been described in certain contexts and may have 
        transcriptional roles.
      action: KEEP_AS_NON_CORE
      reason: Nuclear EGFR is documented but represents a minor, 
        context-dependent localization rather than core EGFR function.
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:17115032
          supporting_text: Tyrosine phosphorylation controls PCNA function 
            through protein stability.

      action: KEEP_AS_NON_CORE
      reason: Downstream effect of EGFR survival signaling.

            through protein stability.
  - term:
      id: GO:0045739
      label: positive regulation of DNA repair
    evidence_type: IDA
    original_reference_id: PMID:17115032

      action: KEEP_AS_NON_CORE
      reason: DNA repair regulation is a non-canonical nuclear EGFR function.

            through protein stability.

      id: GO:0045121
      label: membrane raft
    evidence_type: IDA
    original_reference_id: PMID:12009895

      action: ACCEPT

  - term:

      label: negative regulation of apoptotic process
    evidence_type: IMP
    original_reference_id: PMID:18070883
    review:

        anti-apoptotic pathways including PI3K-AKT.
      action: KEEP_AS_NON_CORE
      reason: Anti-apoptotic effects are downstream consequences of 
        EGFR-PI3K-AKT signaling, not a core function.

      reason: Per GO curation guidelines, 'protein binding' is uninformative and

  - term:
      id: GO:0005768
      label: endosome
    evidence_type: IDA
    original_reference_id: PMID:17182860
    review:
      summary: EGFR localizes to endosomes following ligand-induced 
        internalization. EGFR continues signaling from early endosomes and is 
        subsequently sorted for recycling or lysosomal degradation.
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: Endosomal localization is part of normal EGFR trafficking and 
        signaling. EGFR signals from endosomes and trafficking modulates signal 
        duration.
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:17182860
          supporting_text: Dec 20. Activated Cdc42-associated kinase 1 is a 
            component of EGF receptor signaling complex and regulates EGF 
            receptor degradation.

      label: epidermal growth factor receptor signaling pathway
    evidence_type: IDA
    original_reference_id: PMID:7736574
    review:
      summary: EGFR is the initiating receptor of the EGF receptor signaling 
        pathway, binding EGF family ligands and activating downstream signaling 
        cascades.
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: This is the defining biological process for EGFR - it is the 
        primary receptor that initiates this pathway.
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:7736574
          supporting_text: Three distinct IL-2 signaling pathways mediated by 
            bcl-2, c-myc, and lck cooperate in hematopoietic cell proliferation.

        plasma membrane.
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: EGFR shows polarized distribution in epithelial cells, localizing 
        to basolateral membranes.
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:12646923
          supporting_text: Segregation of receptor and ligand regulates 
            activation of epithelial growth factor receptor.
  - term:
      id: GO:0005515
      label: protein binding
    evidence_type: IPI
    original_reference_id: PMID:11279102
    review:
      summary: Generic 'protein binding' term provides no specific information 
        about EGFR molecular function.
      action: REMOVE
      reason: Per GO curation guidelines, 'protein binding' is uninformative and
        should be replaced with more specific binding terms. EGFR interacts with
        many proteins including ligands (EGF), dimerization partners (ERBB2-4), 
        adaptors (GRB2, SHC), and signaling molecules, but this generic term 
        does not capture any specific binding activity.
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:11279102
          supporting_text: 2001 Mar 8. Sorting nexin 6, a novel SNX, interacts 
            with the transforming growth factor-beta family of receptor 
            serine-threonine kinases.
  - term:
      id: GO:0005886
      label: plasma membrane
    evidence_type: TAS
    original_reference_id: Reactome:R-HSA-1225978
    review:
      summary: EGFR is a transmembrane receptor that localizes to the plasma 
        membrane where it binds extracellular ligands and initiates 
        intracellular signaling.
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: Plasma membrane localization is essential for EGFR function as a 
        cell surface receptor. EGFR resides at the plasma membrane to receive 
        extracellular growth factor signals.

        downstream effect in epithelial tissues.

        about EGFR molecular function.
      action: REMOVE
      reason: Per GO curation guidelines, 'protein binding' is uninformative and
        should be replaced with more specific binding terms. EGFR interacts with

        adaptors (GRB2, SHC), and signaling molecules, but this generic term 
        does not capture any specific binding activity.
      supported_by:

          supporting_text: Epiregulin binds to epidermal growth factor receptor 
            and ErbB-4 and induces tyrosine phosphorylation of epidermal growth 
            factor receptor, ErbB-2, ErbB-3 and ErbB-4.
  - term:
      id: GO:0005515
      label: protein binding
    evidence_type: IPI
    original_reference_id: PMID:2176151
    review:
      summary: Generic 'protein binding' term provides no specific information 
        about EGFR molecular function.
      action: REMOVE
      reason: Per GO curation guidelines, 'protein binding' is uninformative and
        should be replaced with more specific binding terms. EGFR interacts with
        many proteins including ligands (EGF), dimerization partners (ERBB2-4), 
        adaptors (GRB2, SHC), and signaling molecules, but this generic term 
        does not capture any specific binding activity.

          supporting_text: The tyrosine phosphorylated carboxyterminus of the

  - term:
      id: GO:0004709
      label: MAP kinase kinase kinase activity
    evidence_type: NAS
    original_reference_id: PMID:15542601
    review:
      summary: EGFR is not a direct MAP3K. EGFR activates the MAPK cascade but 
        acts upstream of RAF (the actual MAP3K).
      action: MARK_AS_OVER_ANNOTATED
      reason: EGFR is a receptor tyrosine kinase that activates RAS, which then 
        activates RAF (the MAP3K). EGFR itself does not have MAP3K activity.
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:15542601
          supporting_text: 2004 Nov 12. Activation of the epidermal growth 
            factor receptor by respiratory syncytial virus results in increased 
            inflammation and delayed apoptosis.
  - term:
      id: GO:0004713
      label: protein tyrosine kinase activity
    evidence_type: IMP
    original_reference_id: PMID:14702346
    review:
      summary: EGFR possesses protein tyrosine kinase activity, phosphorylating 
        itself and downstream substrates upon activation.
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: Protein tyrosine kinase activity is fundamental to EGFR signaling.
        This is the parent term of transmembrane receptor protein tyrosine 
        kinase activity and accurately describes EGFR function.
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:14702346
          supporting_text: 2003 Dec 31. Sorting of ligand-activated epidermal 
            growth factor receptor to lysosomes requires its actin-binding 
            domain.
  - term:
      id: GO:0005006
      label: epidermal growth factor receptor activity
    evidence_type: IDA
    original_reference_id: PMID:12435727
    review:
      summary: EGFR is the prototypical EGF receptor, binding EGF and related 
        ligands to initiate signaling cascades controlling proliferation, 
        survival, and differentiation.
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: This is the most specific molecular function term for EGFR and is 
        definitionally correct.
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:12435727
          supporting_text: 2002 Nov 14. Epidermal growth factor receptor 
            mediates increased cell proliferation, migration, and aggregation in
            esophageal keratinocytes in vitro and in vivo.
  - term:
      id: GO:0005634
      label: nucleus
    evidence_type: IDA
    original_reference_id: PMID:12828935
    review:
      summary: Nuclear EGFR has been described in certain contexts and may have 
        transcriptional roles.
      action: KEEP_AS_NON_CORE
      reason: Nuclear EGFR is documented but represents a minor, 
        context-dependent localization rather than core EGFR function.
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:12828935
          supporting_text: Activation of epidermal growth factor receptor 
            signals induction of nitric oxide synthase-2 in human optic nerve 
            head astrocytes in glaucomatous optic neuropathy.
  - term:
      id: GO:0005737
      label: cytoplasm
    evidence_type: IDA
    original_reference_id: PMID:12435727
    review:
      summary: EGFR intracellular domain localizes to the cytoplasm.
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: The cytoplasmic portion of EGFR containing the kinase domain is 
        localized in the cytoplasm.
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:12435727
          supporting_text: 2002 Nov 14. Epidermal growth factor receptor 
            mediates increased cell proliferation, migration, and aggregation in
            esophageal keratinocytes in vitro and in vivo.
  - term:
      id: GO:0005768
      label: endosome
    evidence_type: IDA
    original_reference_id: PMID:14702346
    review:
      summary: EGFR localizes to endosomes following ligand-induced 
        internalization. EGFR continues signaling from early endosomes and is 
        subsequently sorted for recycling or lysosomal degradation.
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: Endosomal localization is part of normal EGFR trafficking and 
        signaling. EGFR signals from endosomes and trafficking modulates signal 
        duration.
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:14702346
          supporting_text: 2003 Dec 31. Sorting of ligand-activated epidermal 
            growth factor receptor to lysosomes requires its actin-binding 
            domain.
  - term:
      id: GO:0016020
      label: membrane
    evidence_type: IDA
    original_reference_id: PMID:12435727
    review:
      summary: EGFR is an integral membrane protein spanning the plasma membrane
        with extracellular ligand-binding and intracellular kinase domains.
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: EGFR is a type I transmembrane protein; membrane localization is 
        fundamental to its structure and function.
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:12435727
          supporting_text: 2002 Nov 14. Epidermal growth factor receptor 
            mediates increased cell proliferation, migration, and aggregation in
            esophageal keratinocytes in vitro and in vivo.

      reason: While related to EGFR kinase activity, this describes regulatory

      label: positive regulation of phosphorylation

      action: KEEP_AS_NON_CORE

  - term:
      id: GO:0003690
      label: double-stranded DNA binding
    evidence_type: NAS
    original_reference_id: PMID:6325948
    review:
      summary: Nuclear EGFR has been reported to associate with chromatin, but 
        direct DNA binding is controversial.
      action: MARK_AS_OVER_ANNOTATED
      reason: While nuclear EGFR has been described, its direct DNA binding role
        is not well-established and may be indirect through transcription factor
        interactions.
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:6325948
          supporting_text: ATP-stimulated interaction between epidermal growth 
            factor receptor and supercoiled DNA.

      action: ACCEPT
      reason: Protein tyrosine kinase activity is fundamental to EGFR signaling.
        This is the parent term of transmembrane receptor protein tyrosine

  - term:
      id: GO:0005886
      label: plasma membrane
    evidence_type: IDA
    original_reference_id: PMID:15465819
    review:
      summary: EGFR is a transmembrane receptor that localizes to the plasma 
        membrane where it binds extracellular ligands and initiates 
        intracellular signaling.
      action: ACCEPT
      reason: Plasma membrane localization is essential for EGFR function as a 
        cell surface receptor. EGFR resides at the plasma membrane to receive 
        extracellular growth factor signals.
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: PMID:15465819
          supporting_text: 2004 Oct 1. Ubiquitin ligase activity of c-Cbl guides
            the epidermal growth factor receptor into clathrin-coated pits by 
            two distinct modes of Eps15 recruitment.
  - term:
      id: GO:0018108
      label: peptidyl-tyrosine phosphorylation
    evidence_type: IEA
    review:
      summary: Core catalytic function of EGFR as a receptor tyrosine kinase 
        that phosphorylates substrate proteins on tyrosine residues
      action: NEW
      reason: EGFR is a receptor tyrosine kinase that catalyzes the 
        phosphorylation of tyrosine residues on target substrate proteins. Upon 
        ligand binding and receptor dimerization, EGFR undergoes 
        autophosphorylation of its C-terminal tyrosine residues, which then 
        serve as docking sites for adaptor proteins. EGFR also phosphorylates 
        numerous downstream substrate proteins on tyrosine residues to propagate
        growth factor signaling. This peptidyl-tyrosine phosphorylation activity
        is fundamental to EGFR's mechanism of signal transduction.
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: file:human/EGFR/EGFR-uniprot.txt
          supporting_text: Receptor tyrosine-protein kinase that binds ligands 
            of the EGF family and activates several signaling cascades
  - term:
      id: GO:0046777
      label: protein autophosphorylation
    evidence_type: IEA
    review:
      summary: Essential mechanism of EGFR activation through 
        trans-autophosphorylation of C-terminal tyrosine residues upon 
        ligand-induced dimerization
      action: NEW
      reason: Protein autophosphorylation is the fundamental mechanism by which 
        EGFR activates its signaling cascade. Upon EGF or other ligand binding, 
        EGFR undergoes dimerization, which brings two kinase domains into 
        proximity for trans-autophosphorylation. EGFR phosphorylates multiple 
        tyrosine residues in its own C-terminal tail (including Y1068, Y1086, 
        Y1148, Y1173), creating docking sites for SH2 and PTB domain-containing 
        signaling proteins. This autophosphorylation is essential for EGFR 
        signal transduction and downstream pathway activation.
      supported_by:
        - reference_id: file:human/EGFR/EGFR-uniprot.txt
          supporting_text: Receptor tyrosine-protein kinase that binds ligands 
            of the EGF family and activates several signaling cascades

  - id: PMID:10572067
    title: Dominance of ErbB-1 heterodimers in lung epithelial cells

  - id: PMID:10805725
    title: Class II phosphoinositide 3-kinases are downstream targets of 
      activated polypeptide growth factor receptors.
    findings:
      - statement: PI3K-C2alpha and PI3K-C2beta are recruited to activated EGFR 
          signaling complexes.
        supporting_text: We demonstrate that PI3K-C2alpha and PI3K-C2beta 
          represent two downstream targets of the activated epidermal growth 
          factor (EGF) receptor in human carcinoma-derived A431 cells. 
          Stimulation of quiescent cultures with EGF resulted in the rapid 
          recruitment of both enzymes to a phosphotyrosine signaling complex 
          that contained the EGF receptor and Erb-B2.

  - id: PMID:12620237
    title: EGF activates its receptor by removing interactions that autoinhibit 
      ectodomain dimerization.
    findings:
      - statement: EGF binding relieves autoinhibition of the EGFR ectodomain to
          expose the dimerization interface.
        supporting_text: The structure reveals an autoinhibited configuration, 
          where the dimerization interface recently identified in activated 
          sEGFR structures is completely occluded by intramolecular 
          interactions. To activate the receptor, EGF binding must promote a 
          large domain rearrangement that exposes this dimerization interface.

  - id: PMID:14702346
    title: Sorting of ligand-activated epidermal growth factor receptor to 
      lysosomes requires its actin-binding domain.
    findings:
      - statement: EGFR residues 985-996 are required for lysosomal sorting and 
          degradation after ligand activation.
        supporting_text: Here we demonstrate that the second transport step 
          requires a domain of the EGFR that encompasses residues 985-996 and 
          was previously found to interact with actin. Deletion of domain 
          989-994 (Delta989-994 EGFR) did not interfere with EGFR uptake but 
          completely abrogated its degradation.

  - id: PMID:15282549
    title: LRIG1 restricts growth factor signaling by enhancing receptor 
      ubiquitylation and degradation.
    findings:

          degradation via c-Cbl recruitment.
        supporting_text: Upregulation of LRIG1 is followed by enhanced 
          ubiquitylation and degradation of EGFR. The underlying mechanism 
          involves recruitment of c-Cbl, an E3 ubiquitin ligase that 
          simultaneously ubiquitylates EGFR and LRIG1 and sorts them for 
          degradation.
  - id: PMID:15345710
    title: The leucine-rich repeat protein LRIG1 is a negative regulator of ErbB
      family receptor tyrosine kinases.
    findings:

          ubiquitination and degradation.
        supporting_text: We observed that in co-transfected 293T cells, LRIG1 
          forms a complex with each of the ErbB receptors independent of growth 
          factor binding. We further observed that co-expression of LRIG1 with 
          EGF receptor suppresses cellular receptor levels, shortens receptor 
          half-life, and enhances ligand-stimulated receptor ubiquitination.

          release) and prolonging the survival of RSV-infected cells.

  - id: PMID:15611079
    title: Epigen, the last ligand of ErbB receptors, reveals intricate 
      relationships between affinity and mitogenicity.
    findings:
      - statement: Epigen (EPG) is more mitogenic than EGF despite lower 
          affinity, likely due to inefficient receptor ubiquitylation and 
          down-regulation.
        supporting_text: Interestingly, soluble EPG is more mitogenic than EGF, 
          although its binding affinity is 100-fold lower. Our results attribute
          the anomalous mitogenic power of EPG to evasion of receptor-mediated 
          depletion of ligand molecules, as well as to inefficient receptor 
          ubiquitylation and down-regulation.

      epidermal growth factor receptor.
    findings:
      - statement: EGFR activation is driven by asymmetric kinase domain 
          dimerization rather than activation loop phosphorylation.
        supporting_text: EGFR activation results from the formation of an 
          asymmetric dimer in which the C-terminal lobe of one kinase domain 
          plays a role analogous to that of cyclin in activated CDK/cyclin 
          complexes.

          and is dependent on the tyrosine kinase activity of EGF receptor

      suppression of the EGFR catalytic activity.

          ErbB-binding region.
        supporting_text: We report that RALT suppresses EGFR function by 
          inhibiting its catalytic activity. The evolutionarily conserved 
          ErbB-binding region (EBR) is necessary and sufficient to carry out 
          RALT-dependent suppression of EGFR kinase activity in vitro and in 
          intact cells.
  - id: PMID:17655843
    title: 'EGF receptor transactivation and PI3-kinase mediate stimulation of ERK
      by alpha(2A)-adrenoreceptor in intestinal epithelial cells: a role in wound
      healing.'
    findings:
      - statement: alpha2A-adrenoreceptor activates ERK/Akt via EGFR 
          transactivation in intestinal epithelial cells.
        supporting_text: Both effects are strongly attenuated by inhibition or 
          desensitization of epidermal growth factor (EGF) receptor, matrix 
          metalloproteinase (MMP) blockade, heparin-binding-EGF neutralization 
          or phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3-kinase) inhibitors.
  - id: PMID:17697999
    title: Ligand-induced structural transitions in ErbB receptor extracellular 
      domains.
    findings:
      - statement: Ligand binding shifts EGFR extracellular domain from a 
          tethered autoinhibited state to an extended dimerization-competent 
          conformation.
        supporting_text: Without bound ligand, the extracellular region of the 
          receptor (sEGFR) adopts a "tethered" configuration with its 
          dimerization site occluded by apparently autoinhibitory intramolecular
          interactions. Ligand binding causes the receptor to become "extended,"
          breaking the tether and exposing the dimerization site.
  - id: PMID:17714434
    title: Vps22/EAP30 in ESCRT-II mediates endosomal sorting of growth factor 
      and chemokine receptors destined for lysosomal degradation.
    findings:
      - statement: Vps22 is required for ligand-induced EGFR degradation and 
          proper endosomal sorting.
        supporting_text: Depletion of Vps22 by small interfering RNA, which was 
          accompanied by decreased levels of other ESCRT-II subunits, greatly 
          reduced degradation of EGFR and its ligand EGF as well as the 
          chemokine receptor CXCR4.
  - id: PMID:17726113
    title: Inhibition of the leucine-rich repeat protein LINGO-1 enhances 
      survival, structure, and function of dopaminergic neurons in Parkinson's 
      disease models.
    findings:
      - statement: LINGO-1 antagonists improve dopaminergic neuron survival via 
          EGFR/Akt activation by blocking LINGO-1 binding to EGFR.
        supporting_text: LINGO-1 antagonists (LINGO-1-Fc, dominant negative 
          LINGO-1, and anti-LINGO-1 antibody) improved DA neuron survival in 
          response to MPP+ in part by mechanisms that involve activation of the 
          EGFR/Akt signaling pathway through a direct inhibition of LINGO-1's 
          binding to EGFR.
  - id: PMID:17909029
    title: The phosphoinositide kinase PIKfyve mediates epidermal growth factor 
      receptor trafficking to the nucleus.
    findings:
      - statement: PIKfyve mediates HB-EGF-stimulated EGFR nuclear trafficking 
          and EGFR binding to the cyclin D1 promoter.
        supporting_text: RNA silencing indicated that PIKfyve is a mediator of 
          HB-EGF-stimulated EGFR nuclear trafficking, EGFR binding to the cyclin
          D1 promoter, and cell cycle progression.
  - id: PMID:18042729
    title: Epidermal growth factor receptor juxtamembrane region regulates 
      allosteric tyrosine kinase activation.
    findings:
      - statement: The EGFR juxtamembrane region is required for allosteric 
          kinase activation.
        supporting_text: Deletion of the JM region (DeltaJM) results in a severe
          loss of ICD tyrosine phosphorylation, indicating that this region is 
          required for maximal activity of the tyrosine kinase domain.
  - id: PMID:18046415
    title: Inhibition of the EGF receptor by binding of MIG6 to an activating 
      kinase domain interface.
    findings:
      - statement: MIG6 inhibits EGFR by blocking formation of the activating 
          asymmetric dimer interface.
        supporting_text: Biochemical and cell-based analyses confirm that this 
          interaction contributes to EGFR inhibition by blocking the formation 
          of the activating dimer interface.
  - id: PMID:18070883
    title: A novel role of Sprouty 2 in regulating cellular apoptosis.
    findings:
      - statement: Spry2 supports EGFR signaling and survival pathways; its 
          silencing reduces EGFR levels and EGF-elicited AKT/ERK activation.
        supporting_text: Silencing of hSPRY2 decreased serum- or epidermal 
          growth factor (EGF)-elicited activation of AKT and ERK1/2 and reduced 
          the levels of EGF receptor.
  - id: PMID:18273061
    title: Structural basis for a novel intrapeptidyl H-bond and reverse binding
      of c-Cbl-TKB domain substrates.
    findings:
      - statement: The c-Cbl TKB domain binds phosphorylated EGFR peptides as 
          substrates for ubiquitination.
        supporting_text: To address how this domain can bind to disparate 
          recognition mofits and to determine whether this results in variations
          in substrate-binding affinity, we compared crystal structures of the 
          Cbl-TKB domain complexed with phosphorylated peptides of Sprouty2, 
          Sprouty4, epidermal growth factor receptor, Syk, and c-Met receptors 
          and validated the binding with point-mutational analyses using 
          full-length proteins
  - id: PMID:18455122
    title: Survival of cancer cells is maintained by EGFR independent of its 
      kinase activity.
    findings:
      - statement: Kinase-independent EGFR maintains survival by stabilizing 
          SGLT1 and preventing autophagic death.
        supporting_text: the function of kinase-independent EGFR is to prevent 
          autophagic cell death by maintaining intracellular glucose level 
          through interaction and stabilization of the sodium/glucose 
          cotransporter 1 (SGLT1).
  - id: PMID:18483258
    title: UVA-induced cell cycle progression is mediated by a disintegrin and 
      metalloprotease/epidermal growth factor receptor/AKT/Cyclin D1 pathways in
      keratinocytes.
    findings:
      - statement: UVA activates EGFR upstream of AKT/cyclin D1 to drive cell 
          cycle progression in keratinocytes.
        supporting_text: Activation of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) 
          was observed after UVA exposure. EGFR kinase inhibitor AG attenuated 
          the UVA-induced AKT/cyclin D1 pathway and cell cycle progression, 
          indicating that EGFR is upstream of AKT/cyclin D1 pathway activation.
  - id: PMID:18542056
    title: LRIG1 negatively regulates the oncogenic EGF receptor mutant 
      EGFRvIII.
    findings:
      - statement: LRIG1 binds EGFRvIII and suppresses its oncogenic signaling.
        supporting_text: We find that EGFRvIII retains interaction with LRIG1 
          and is in fact more sensitive to LRIG1 action than wild-type receptor.
  - id: PMID:18602463
    title: Ataxin-2 associates with the endocytosis complex and affects EGF 
      receptor trafficking.
    findings:
      - statement: Ataxin-2 influences EGFR endocytic trafficking.
        supporting_text: Functional studies demonstrated that ataxin-2 affects 
          endocytic trafficking of the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR).
  - id: PMID:18722344
    title: BCAR3 regulates EGF-induced DNA synthesis in normal human breast 
      MCF-12A cells.
    findings:
      - statement: BCAR3 associates with activated EGFR and is required for 
          EGF-induced DNA synthesis.
        supporting_text: Direct association of BCAR3 with activated EGF receptor
          and Cas was observed.
  - id: PMID:18776048
    title: Comparisons of tyrosine phosphorylated proteins in cells expressing 
      lung cancer-specific alleles of EGFR and KRAS.
    findings:
      - statement: Mutant EGFR increases tyrosine phosphorylation of signaling 
          proteins relative to WT EGFR.
        supporting_text: Tyrosine phosphorylation of signaling molecules was 
          greater in HBECs expressing the mutant EGFRs than in cells expressing 
          WT EGFR or mutant KRAS.
  - id: PMID:18824549
    title: Acidic mammalian chitinase is secreted via an ADAM17/epidermal growth
      factor receptor-dependent pathway and stimulates chemokine production by 
      pulmonary epithelial cells.
    findings:
      - statement: AMCase secretion is EGFR-dependent and involves EGFR 
          interaction.
        supporting_text: In vitro cotransfection experiments in A549 cells 
          demonstrated that AMCase and EGFR physically interact with each other.
          Cotransfection of AMCase and EGFR also increased, whereas EGFR 
          inhibition decreased AMCase secretion.
  - id: PMID:19167335
    title: Large-scale structural analysis of the classical human protein 
      tyrosine phosphatome.
    findings:
      - statement: Protein tyrosine phosphatases regulate signaling by 
          selectively dephosphorylating substrates.
        supporting_text: Protein tyrosine phosphatases (PTPs) play a critical 
          role in regulating cellular functions by selectively dephosphorylating
          their substrates.
  - id: PMID:19172738
    title: Phosphorylation-dependent binding of 14-3-3 terminates signalling by 
      the Gab2 docking protein.
    findings:
      - statement: 14-3-3 binding to phosphorylated Gab2 terminates 
          receptor-associated signaling by uncoupling Gab2 from Grb2.
        supporting_text: We now demonstrate that growth factor-induced 
          phosphorylation of Gab2 on two residues, S210 and T391, leads to 
          recruitment of 14-3-3 proteins.
  - id: PMID:19509291
    title: GAREM, a novel adaptor protein for growth factor receptor-bound 
      protein 2, contributes to cellular transformation through the activation 
      of extracellular signal-regulated kinase signaling.
    findings:
      - statement: GAREM is phosphorylated after EGF stimulation and binds Grb2 
          to regulate ERK signaling downstream of EGFR.
        supporting_text: GAREM is phosphorylated at tyrosine 105 and 453 after 
          EGF stimulation. Grb2 was identified as its binding partner, and the 
          proline-rich motifs of GAREM are recognized by the N- and C-terminal 
          SH3 domains of Grb2.
  - id: PMID:19563760
    title: Mechanism for activation of the EGF receptor catalytic domain by the 
      juxtamembrane segment.
    findings:
      - statement: The EGFR juxtamembrane segment promotes kinase activation by 
          dimerizing kinase domains.
        supporting_text: We show that the intracellular juxtamembrane segment of
          the receptor, known to potentiate kinase activity, is able to dimerize
          the kinase domains.
  - id: PMID:19602593
    title: Cetuximab/C225-induced intracellular trafficking of epidermal growth 
      factor receptor.
    findings:

          and nucleus.
        supporting_text: The data herein show that C225-dependent EGFR 
          trafficking relocalizes the receptor to the endoplasmic reticulum (ER)
          and nucleus.
  - id: PMID:19650109

        supporting_text: The in situ proximity ligation assay (in situ PLA) was 
          used to quantify homo- and heteromeric interactions between EGFR and 
          HER2 in cultured cells, using flow cytometry as the readout method.
  - id: PMID:19798056

      receptor.

      - statement: Tom1L1 is required for EGFR endocytosis following EGF 
          stimulation.
        supporting_text: RNAi-mediated knockdown of Tom1L1 inhibits endocytosis 
          of EGFR.
  - id: PMID:20007378
    title: Structural analysis of the catalytically inactive kinase domain of 
      the human EGF receptor 3.
    findings:
      - statement: HER3 is catalytically inactive but can activate the EGFR 
          kinase domain.
        supporting_text: we confirm that it is catalytically inactive but can 
          serve as an activator of the EGFR kinase domain.
  - id: PMID:20029029
    title: Regulation of epidermal growth factor receptor trafficking by lysine 
      deacetylase HDAC6.
    findings:
      - statement: HDAC6 negatively regulates EGFR endocytosis and degradation 
          by controlling tubulin acetylation.
        supporting_text: histone deacetylase 6 (HDAC6), a cytoplasmic lysine 
          deacetylase, which we found negatively regulated EGFR endocytosis and 
          degradation
  - id: PMID:20153921
    title: EGFR and EGFRvIII interact with PUMA to inhibit mitochondrial 
      translocalization of PUMA and PUMA-mediated apoptosis independent of EGFR 
      kinase activity.
    findings:
      - statement: EGFR/EGFRvIII bind PUMA and sequester it in the cytoplasm, 
          inhibiting apoptosis independently of EGFR kinase activity.
        supporting_text: EGFR/EGFRvIII binds to PUMA constitutively and under 
          apoptotic stress, and subsequently sequesters PUMA in the cytoplasm. 
          The EGFR-PUMA interaction is independent of EGFR activation and is 
          sustained under EGFR inhibition.
  - id: PMID:20302655
    title: Epidermal growth factor receptor regulates beta-catenin location, 
      stability, and transcriptional activity in oral cancer.
    findings:
      - statement: EGFR activation increases nuclear beta-catenin and regulates 
          its transcriptional activity in oral cancer.
        supporting_text: Activation of EGFR signaling increased the amount of 
          beta-catenin in the nucleus and decreased the amount in the membranes.
  - id: PMID:20308550
    title: The phosphatase and tensin homolog regulates epidermal growth factor 
      receptor (EGFR) inhibitor response by targeting EGFR for degradation.
    findings:
      - statement: PTEN inactivation elevates EGFR activity by impairing 
          Cbl-mediated ubiquitylation and degradation.
        supporting_text: PTEN inactivation specifically raises EGFR activity by 
          impairing the ligand-induced ubiquitylation and degradation of the 
          activated receptor through destabilization of newly formed ubiquitin 
          ligase Cbl complexes.
  - id: PMID:20359299
    title: 'A proximity ligation assay using transiently transfected, epitope-tagged
      proteins: application for in situ detection of dimerized receptor tyrosine kinases.'

          ligand-dependent EGFR dimerization.
        supporting_text: utility of a proximity ligation assay (PLA)-based 
          methodology for in situ visualization and quantification of 
          ligand-dependent EGFR receptor dimerization in intact cells.
  - id: PMID:20403327
    title: TRP channel regulates EGFR signaling in hair morphogenesis and skin 
      barrier formation.
    findings:
      - statement: TRPV3 forms a signaling complex with TGF-alpha/EGFR and 
          amplifies EGFR signaling via TGF-alpha release.
        supporting_text: keratinocyte TRPV3, a member of the transient receptor 
          potential (TRP) family of Ca(2+)-permeant channels, forms a signaling 
          complex with TGF-alpha/EGFR. Activation of EGFR leads to increased 
          TRPV3 channel activity, which in turn stimulates TGF-alpha release.
  - id: PMID:20462955
    title: A G{alpha}i-GIV molecular complex binds epidermal growth factor 
      receptor and determines whether cells migrate or proliferate.
    findings:
      - statement: GIV directly interacts with EGFR and enhances EGFR 
          autophosphorylation while prolonging membrane association.
        supporting_text: GIV directly interacts with EGFR, and when its GEF 
          function is intact, a Galpha(i)-GIV-EGFR signaling complex assembles, 
          EGFR autophosphorylation is enhanced, and the receptor's association 
          with the plasma membrane (PM) is prolonged.
  - id: PMID:20473329

      inhibit glioblastoma cell transformation and migration.

          inhibits EGFRvIII-driven migration and transformation.
        supporting_text: We observed reduced EGFRvIII/SHP-2/Gab1/Grb2/Sos-1 
          interaction and enhanced SIRP/SHP-2 association in 
          U87MG.EGFRvIII/SIRPalpha1 cells when compared with empty vector 
          control cells.

      cancer-associated fibroblasts.

          phosphorylated EGFR at the cyclin D1 promoter.
        supporting_text: E2 stimulates a physical interaction between GPR30 and 
          phosphorylated EGFR, recruiting them to the cyclin D1 gene promoter.
  - id: PMID:20562913

      EGFR-mediated signaling and motility in prostate cancer cells.
    findings:
      - statement: ERK inhibition enhances EGF-induced EGFR activation, 
          ubiquitination, and downregulation.
        supporting_text: pharmacological inhibition of ERK (but not Akt) 
          signaling enhances EGF-induced EGFR activation, ubiquitination and 
          downregulation
  - id: PMID:20624308
    title: EGFR/Met association regulates EGFR TKI resistance in breast cancer.
    findings:
      - statement: EGFR and Met form a complex that supports ligand-independent 
          Met phosphorylation and EGFR TKI resistance.
        supporting_text: we identified an EGFR/Met complex via 
          co-immunoprecipitation. However, we only observed Met constitutive 
          phosphorylation when c-Src also was part of this complex.
  - id: PMID:20878056

  - id: PMID:20935677

          complex and mediated estrogen-induced phosphorylation of epidermal

  - id: PMID:21203579
    title: HER2 phosphorylation is maintained by a PKB negative feedback loop in
      response to anti-HER2 herceptin in breast cancer.
    findings:
      - statement: HER2 phosphorylation is maintained by ligand-mediated 
          EGFR/HER3/HER4 activation via ADAM17.
        supporting_text: HER2 phosphorylation is maintained by ligand-mediated 
          activation of EGFR, HER3, and HER4 receptors, resulting in their 
          dimerisation with HER2. The release of HER ligands was mediated by 
          ADAM17 through a PKB negative feedback loop.
  - id: PMID:21258405
    title: Galectin-3 regulates MUC1 and EGFR cellular distribution and EGFR 
      downstream pathways in pancreatic cancer cells.
    findings:
      - statement: Galectin-3 promotes endocytosis of EGFR; its depletion 
          increases EGFR phosphorylation and nuclear translocation.
        supporting_text: galectin-3, an endogenous lectin, is co-expressed with 
          MUC1 in human pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma, and that it favours 
          the endocytosis of MUC1 and EGFR. Depletion of galectin-3 by RNA 
          interference increased the interaction between MUC1 and EGFR, EGFR and
          ERK-1,2 phosphorylation, and translocation of EGFR to the nucleus.
  - id: PMID:21266349
    title: EGFR nuclear translocation modulates DNA repair following cisplatin 
      and ionizing radiation treatment.
    findings:
      - statement: EGFR nuclear localization and DNA-PKcs binding enhance DNA 
          repair after cisplatin or IR.
        supporting_text: Immunoprecipitation showed wtEGFR and EGFRvIII binding 
          to DNA-PKcs, increasing 2-fold 18 hours after cisplatin therapy.
  - id: PMID:21278786
    title: PI3K inhibition results in enhanced HER signaling and acquired ERK 
      dependency in HER2-overexpressing breast cancer.

      - statement: PI3K inhibition enhances HER receptor dimerization and 
          phosphorylation, including EGFR, leading to ERK activation.
        supporting_text: This enhanced ERK signaling occurred as a result of 
          activation of HER family receptors as evidenced by induction of HER 
          receptors dimerization and phosphorylation, increased expression of 
          HER3 and binding of adaptor molecules to HER2 and HER3.

  - id: PMID:21349850

      activation.

          autophosphorylation.
        supporting_text: In IQGAP1-null cells, EGF-stimulated tyrosine 
          phosphorylation of EGFR is severely attenuated. Normal levels of 
          autophosphorylation are restored by reconstituting wild type IQGAP1 
          and enhanced by an IQGAP1 S1443D mutant.

  - id: PMID:21480528
    title: Comparative analysis of fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET)
      and proximity ligation assay (PLA).
    findings:
      - statement: PLA is semiquantitative due to signal saturation, whereas 
          FRET signals scale linearly with expression.
        supporting_text: Our data imply that PLA is a semiquantitative measure 
          of protein colocalizations due to non-linear effects in the reaction 
          and that caution should be exercised when interpreting PLA data in a 
          quantitative way.
  - id: PMID:21482778

          dimerization/activation and surface transport of receptor protein 
          kinases--EGF receptor and TrkB--at early stages of their

  - id: PMID:9506989
    title: Grb10 interacts differentially with the insulin receptor, 
      insulin-like growth factor I receptor, and epidermal growth factor 
      receptor via the Grb10 Src homology 2 (SH2) domain and a second novel 
      domain located between the pleckstrin homology and SH2 domains.

  - id: PMID:9544989
    title: Shc phosphotyrosine-binding domain dominantly interacts with 
      epidermal growth factor receptors and mediates Ras activation in intact 
      cells.

  - id: PMID:9852145
    title: Interaction of ZPR1 with translation elongation factor-1alpha in

  - id: PMID:9890893
    title: Identification of tyrosine phosphorylation sites in human Gab-1 
      protein by EGF receptor kinase in vitro.
    findings: []
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-1169421
    title: Trans-autophosphorylation of activated ligand-responsive EGFR mutant 
      dimers
    findings:
      - statement: Ligand-responsive EGFR mutant dimers trans-autophosphorylate 
          multiple tyrosine residues after activation.
        supporting_text: Activation of ligand-responsive EGFR mutants through 
          spontaneous or EGF-induced dimerization results in 
          trans-autophosphorylation of 5 tyrosine residues
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-1218833
    title: Binding of ligand-responsive EGFR mutants to chaperoning proteins 
      HSP90 and CDC37
    findings:
      - statement: EGFR kinase domain mutants require continuous association 
          with HSP90 for proper functioning.
        supporting_text: EGFR kinase domain mutants need continuous association 
          with HSP90 chaperone protein for proper functioning.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-1220610
    title: Non-covalent tyrosine kinase inhibitors bind and inactivate sensitive
      ligand-responsive EGFR cancer mutants
    findings:
      - statement: Reversible TKIs inhibit mutant EGFR autophosphorylation by 
          competitively blocking ATP binding.
        supporting_text: Non-covalent (reversible) tyrosine kinase inhibitors 
          (TKIs), erlotinib, gefitinib, lapatinib and vandetanib, selectively 
          inhibit EGFR-stimulated tumor cell growth by blocking EGFR mutant 
          autophosphorylation through competitive inhibition of ATP binding to 
          the kinase domain.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-1220611
    title: Covalent tyrosine kinase inhibitors bind and inactivate EGFR kinase 
      domain mutant dimers resistant to non-covalent tyrosine kinase inhibitors
    findings:
      - statement: Covalent TKIs bind EGFR C397 and inhibit 
          trans-autophosphorylation of mutants resistant to non-covalent TKIs.
        supporting_text: Covalent (irreversible) tyrosine kinase inhibitors 
          (TKIs), pelitinib, WZ4002, HKI-272, canertinib and afatinib, form a 
          covalent bond with the EGFR cysteine residue C397 and inhibit 
          trans-autophosphorylation of mutants resistant to non-covalent TKIs.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-1220612
    title: Binding of EGF to ligand-responsive EGFR mutants
    findings:
      - statement: Ligand-responsive EGFR mutants bind EGF and show increased 
          activity in its presence.
        supporting_text: Ligand-responsive EGFR mutants are able to bind EGF and
          exhibit increased activity in the presence of EGF.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-1220613
    title: EGF-induced dimerization of ligand-responsive EGFR mutants
    findings:
      - statement: EGF increases dimerization of ligand-responsive EGFR mutants.
        supporting_text: Although ligand-responsive EGFR mutants dimerize 
          spontaneously, dimerization is increased in the presence of EGF.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-1220614
    title: Spontaneous dimerization of ligand-responsive EGFR mutants
    findings:
      - statement: Ligand-responsive EGFR mutants spontaneously dimerize without
          ligand binding.
        supporting_text: EGFR ligand-responsive mutants dimerize spontaneously, 
          without ligand binding, although ligand binding ability is preserved.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-1225947
    title: Binding of SHC1 to p-6Y-EGFR mutants
    findings:
      - statement: SHC1 binds phosphorylated EGFR docking sites Y1148 and Y1173 
          in EGFR mutants.
        supporting_text: "SHC1 (Src homology 2 domain-containing transforming protein)
          is known to bind two phosphorylated tyrosine docking sites of EGFR: Y1148
          and Y1173"
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-1225949
    title: Binding of CBL to ligand-responsive p-6Y-EGFR mutants
    findings:
      - statement: CBL binds phosphorylated Y1069 (Y1045) on EGFR cancer 
          mutants.
        supporting_text: CBL binds to phosphorylated tyrosine Y1069 (i.e. Y1045 
          in the mature protein) residue of EGFR cancer mutants.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-1225950
    title: Binding of GRB2:SOS1 complex to phosphorylated ligand-responsive EGFR
      mutants
    findings:
      - statement: GRB2 binds phosphorylated EGFR mutant tyrosines Y1068 and 
          Y1086.
        supporting_text: GRB2 binds to phosphorylated tyrosine residues Y1068 
          and Y1086
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-1225951
    title: SOS-mediated nucleotide exchange of RAS (mediated by GRB2:SOS1 in 
      complex with ligand-responsive p-6Y-EGFR mutants)
    findings:
      - statement: SOS1 recruited via GRB2 to phosphorylated EGFR mutants 
          activates RAS.
        supporting_text: Based on the wild-type EGFR signaling, it is assumed 
          that the guanine nucleotide exchange factor SOS1 interacts with 
          phosphorylated EGFR mutants through the adaptor protein, GRB2. Upon 
          formation of this complex, SOS1 activates RAS by promoting GDP release
          and GTP binding.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-1225952
    title: Phosphorylation of SHC1 by ligand-responsive p-6Y-EGFR mutants
    findings:
      - statement: EGFR L858R mutant constitutively phosphorylates SHC1.
        supporting_text: Constitutive phosphorylation of SHC1 was directly 
          demonstrated in cells expressing EGFR L858R mutant (Greulich et al. 
          2005).
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-1225956
    title: Inefficient ubiquitination of ligand-responsive p-6Y-EGFR mutants by 
      p-Y371-CBL
    findings:
      - statement: Phosphorylated CBL does not efficiently ubiquitinate EGFR 
          kinase domain mutants.
        supporting_text: Phosphorylated CBL does not ubiquitinate EGFR kinase 
          domain mutants efficiently, which enables mutant proteins to escape 
          degradation.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-1225957
    title: SOS-mediated nucleotide exchange of RAS (mediated by GRB2:SOS1 in 
      complex with phosphorylated SHC1 and ligand-responsive p-6Y-EGFR mutants)
    findings:
      - statement: GRB2-bound SOS1 is assumed to activate RAS downstream of 
          p-SHC1:p-EGFR mutants.
        supporting_text: SOS1, recruited by GRB2 bound to p-SHC1:p-EGFR mutants,
          is assumed to activate RAS nucleotide exchange from the inactive form 
          (bound to GDP) to an active form (bound to GTP).
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-1225960
    title: Phosphorylation of CBL by ligand-responsive p-6Y-EGFR mutants
    findings:
      - statement: EGFR L858R mutant directly phosphorylates CBL on Y371.
        supporting_text: EGFR L858R mutant was shown to directly phosphorylate 
          CBL on tyrosine residue Y371.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-1225961
    title: Phosphorylated SHC1 in complex with ligand-responsive p-6Y-EGFR 
      mutants recruits GRB2:SOS1 complex
    findings:
      - statement: SHC1 bound to phosphorylated EGFR mutant dimers is assumed to
          recruit GRB2:SOS1.
        supporting_text: Recruitment of GRB2:SOS1 complex by SHC1 bound to 
          phosphorylated dimers of EGFR cancer mutants has not been directly 
          tested, but is assumed to happen in the same way it happens with the 
          SHC1 bound to the phosphorylated homodimer of wild-type EGFR.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-1225978
    title: Covalent tyrosine kinase inhibitors bind and inhibit wild-type 
      EGF:EGFR dimers
    findings:
      - statement: Covalent TKIs inhibit wild-type EGFR by covalently binding 
          Cys397.
        supporting_text: Covalent (irreversible) TKIs, pelitinib, WZ4002, 
          HKI-272, canertinib and afatinib, inhibit the wild-type EGFR through 
          formation of the covalent bond with the cysteine residue C397.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-1226012
    title: Binding of PI3K to complex of GRB2:GAB1 and ligand-responsive 
      p-6Y-EGFR mutants
    findings:
      - statement: EGFR cancer mutants are assumed to recruit PI3K in a manner 
          similar to wild-type EGFR.
        supporting_text: EGFR cancer mutants are assumed to recruit the PI3K 
          complex PIK3CA:PIK3R1 in a manner similar to wild-type EGFR.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-1226014
    title: Conversion of PIP2 to PIP3 by PI3K bound to ligand-responsive 
      p-6Y-EGFR mutants
    findings:
      - statement: EGFR cancer mutants are assumed to induce PI3K/AKT signaling 
          via PI3K-mediated conversion of PIP2 to PIP3.
        supporting_text: The kinase activity of PI3K mediates the 
          phosphorylation of PIP2 to form PIP3. It is assumed that EGFR cancer 
          mutants induce PI3K/AKT signaling in a manner similar to wild-type 
          EGFR.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-1226016
    title: Binding of GRB2:GAB1 complex to ligand-responsive p-6Y-EGFR mutants
    findings:
      - statement: Recruitment of GRB2:GAB1 to phosphorylated EGFR cancer 
          mutants is assumed and not directly tested.
        supporting_text: Direct binding of GRB2:GAB1 complex to phosphorylated 
          homodimers of EGFR cancer mutants has not been tested.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-1247841
    title: PLCG1 binds to ligand-responsive p-6Y-EGFR mutants
    findings:
      - statement: EGFR cancer mutants phosphorylate Y992 and are expected to 
          recruit PLCG1 similarly to wild-type EGFR.
        supporting_text: Tyrosine residue Y992 (corresponding to Y1016 when 
          counting from the first amino acid of the EGFR precursor, prior to 
          cleavage of the 24-amino acid signal peptide at the N-terminus), a 
          docking site for PLC-gamma 1 (PLCG1), is phosphorylated in EGFR cancer
          mutants and expected to recruit PLC-gamma 1 in the same way as the 
          wild-type EGFR receptor.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-1247842
    title: Dissociation of phosphorylated PLCG1 from ligand-responsive p-6Y-EGFR
      mutants
    findings:
      - statement: After EGFR mutant-driven phosphorylation, PLCG1 is expected 
          to dissociate, a release event following activation rather than an 
          active EGFR role at this step.
        supporting_text: Once phosphorylated, PLC-gamma 1 is expected to 
          dissociate from phosphorylated EGFR cancer mutants and induce 
          downstream signaling in the same way it does when activated by the 
          wild-type EGFR.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-1247844
    title: Phosphorylation of PLCG1 by ligand-responsive p-6Y-EGFR mutants
    findings:
      - statement: EGFR cancer mutants are assumed to phosphorylate PLCG1 after 
          recruitment.
        supporting_text: Once recruited, PLC-gamma 1 is assumed to be 
          phosphorylated by EGFR cancer mutants in the same way it is 
          phosphorylated by the wild-type EGFR.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-1247999
    title: EGFRvIII mutant binds chaperone proteins HSP90 and CDC37
    findings:
      - statement: EGFRvIII requires HSP90 and CDC37 chaperones for proper 
          function.
        supporting_text: Association of EGFRvIII mutant with HSP90 chaperone 
          protein and its co-chaperone CDC37 is necessary for the proper 
          functioning of mutant EGFR.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-1248002
    title: Ligand-independent dimerization of EGFRvIII mutant
    findings:
      - statement: EGFRvIII cannot bind ligand but dimerizes spontaneously, 
          potentially influenced by N-linked glycosylation.
        supporting_text: EGFRvIII mutant lacks the ligand binding domain and is 
          therefore unable to bind EGFR ligands, but is able to dimerize 
          spontaneously. Self-dimerization may be dependent on N-linked 
          glycosylation.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-1248655
    title: Trans-autophosphorylation of EGFRvIII mutant dimers
    findings:
      - statement: EGFRvIII dimers trans-autophosphorylate multiple tyrosines 
          while Y1045 remains hypo/unphosphorylated, enabling signaling and 
          reduced downregulation.
        supporting_text: Upon dimerization, EGFRvIII mutants 
          trans-autophosphorylate on tyrosine residues Y1016 i.e. Y992 in the 
          mature protein, Y1092 i.e. Y1068 in the mature protein, Y1110 i.e. 
          Y0186 in the mature protein, Y1172 i.e. Y1148 in the mature protein 
          and Y1197 i.e. Y1173 in the mature protein, while the tyrosine residue
          Y1069 i.e. Y1045 in the mature protein, a docking site for CBL, 
          remains either unphosphorylated or hypophosphorylated, allowing 
          EGFRvIII to activate downstream signaling cascades while escaping 
          downregulation.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-1248677
    title: Inactivation of over-expressed wild type EGFR by Cetuximab 
      recombinant antibody
    findings:
      - statement: Cetuximab inhibits EGFR by blocking ligand binding and 
          promoting receptor inactivation and degradation.
        supporting_text: Cetuximab binds to the extracellular domain of EGFR and
          blocks ligand binding, leading to receptor inactivation, 
          internalization and degradation.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-1250195
    title: SHC1 phosphorylation by ERBB2 heterodimers
    findings:
      - statement: In ERBB2 heterodimers, EGFR can phosphorylate SHC1 on 
          tyrosine residues.
        supporting_text: Once bound to ERBB2 heterodimers, SHC1 is 
          phosphorylated on tyrosine residues by the tyrosine kinase activity of
          either ERBB2 or its heterodimerization partners EGFR and ERBB4 
          (Segatto et al. 1993, Soler et al. 1994).
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-1306957
    title: PIP2 to PIP3 conversion by PI3K bound to GRB2:GAB1 in complex with 
      phosphorylated heterodimer of ERBB2 and EGFR
    findings:
      - statement: PI3K associated with phosphorylated ERBB2:EGFR converts PIP2 
          to PIP3 to activate AKT signaling.
        supporting_text: Active PI3K in complex with p-EGFR:p-ERBB2:GRB2:GAB1 
          phosphorylates PIP2 into PIP3, leading to activation of AKT signaling 
          (Jackson et al. 2004).
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-1306963
    title: Binding of GRB2:GAB1 to p-ERBB2:p-EGFR
    findings:
      - statement: GRB2:GAB1 is recruited to activated ERBB2:EGFR via 
          phosphorylated docking tyrosines.
        supporting_text: GAB1 in complex with GRB2 is recruited to activated 
          ERBB2:EGFR heterodimer through phosphorylated tyrosine residues that 
          serve as docking sites for GRB2 (Jackson et al. 2004).
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-1306965
    title: Binding of PI3K to GRB2:GAB1 in complex with phosphorylated 
      heterodimer of ERBB2 and EGFR
    findings:
      - statement: PI3K activation follows PIK3R1 binding to GRB2:GAB1 in 
          complex with phosphorylated ERBB2:EGFR.
        supporting_text: Binding of PIK3R1 to GRB2:GAB1 in complex with 
          phosphorylated heterodimer of ERBB2 and EGFR triggers a conformational
          change in the PI3K complex, resulting in PI3K activation (Jackson et 
          al. 2004).
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-177922
    title: EGFR dimerization
    findings:
      - statement: EGF binding stabilizes the active dimeric form of EGFR.
        supporting_text: EGF and other growth factors induce oligomerization of 
          their specific receptors. Inactive EGFR monomers are in equilibrium 
          with active EGFR dimers and binding of the EGF ligand stabilizes the 
          active dimeric form.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-177923
    title: Sustained activation of SRC kinase by SHP2
    findings:
      - statement: SHP2-mediated dephosphorylation of paxillin promotes SRC 
          activation in EGF-stimulated signaling.
        supporting_text: SHP2 can dephosphorylate paxillin, which leads to CSK 
          dissociation from the paxillin-SRC complex and SRC activation.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-177924
    title: Dephosphorylation of Gab1 by SHP2
    findings:
      - statement: SHP2 dephosphorylation of GAB1 blocks PI3K binding and 
          activation.
        supporting_text: SHP2 dephosphorylation of the tyrosine residues 447, 
          472 and 589 on GAB1 means PI3 kinase can no longer bind to the complex
          in the plasma membrane and cannot be activated.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-177925
    title: SHC1 binds to the phosphorylated EGF receptor:ligand complex
    findings:
      - statement: SHC1 binds phosphorylated EGFR at Y1148 or Y1173 sites.
        supporting_text: SHC1 (Src homology 2 domain-containing) transforming 
          protein can bind to either phosphorylated tyrosine sites Y1172 
          (p-Y1172) i.e. Y1148 (p-Y1148) in the mature protein and/or tyrosine 
          Y1197 (p-Y1197) i.e. Y1173 (p-Y1173) in the mature protein on the EGF 
          receptor.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-177926
    title: Dephosphorylation of PAG by SHP2
    findings:
      - statement: SHP2 dephosphorylation of CBP/PAG reduces recruitment of Csk 
          and limits Src inhibition.
        supporting_text: Dephosphorylation of CBP/PAG negatively regulates the 
          recruitment of the Src inhibiting kinase, Csk.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-177927
    title: PI3K binds to EGF:EGFR:GRB2:GAB1
    findings:
      - statement: PI3K regulatory subunit PIK3R1 binds GAB1 to recruit PI3K to 
          EGFR signaling complexes.
        supporting_text: The Src homology 2 (SH2) domain of the 
          phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PIK3) regulatory subunit (PIK3R1, i.e. 
          PI3Kp85) binds to GAB1 in a phosphorylation-independent manner.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-177929
    title: Signaling by EGFR
    findings:
      - statement: EGFR ligand binding triggers dimerization and 
          trans-autophosphorylation to initiate downstream signaling.
        supporting_text: Binding of EGFR to its ligands induces conformational 
          change that unmasks the dimerization interface in the extracellular 
          domain of EGFR, leading to receptor homo- or heterodimerization at the
          cell surface. Dimerization of the extracellular regions of EGFR 
          triggers additional conformational change of the cytoplasmic EGFR 
          regions, enabling the kinase domains of two EGFR molecules to achieve 
          the catalytically active conformation. Ligand activated EGFR dimers 
          trans-autophosphorylate on tyrosine residues in the cytoplasmic tail 
          of the receptor.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-177930
    title: GAB1 phosphorylation by EGFR kinase
    findings:
      - statement: EGFR kinase phosphorylates GAB1 at Y627 and Y659.
        supporting_text: EGFR kinase phosphorylates the phosphorylation sites 
          tyrosine 627 and 659 on GAB1
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-177933
    title: SHC1 phosphorylation by phosphorylated EGFR
    findings:
      - statement: EGFR-bound SHC1 is phosphorylated on Y349 and Y350.
        supporting_text: Once bound to EGFR, SHC1 is phosphorylated on two 
          tyrosines (Y349, Y350).
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-177934
    title: EGFR autophosphorylation
    findings:
      - statement: EGFR dimerization activates kinase activity and leads to 
          autophosphorylation of six tyrosines in the cytoplasmic tail.
        supporting_text: Dimerization of EGFR activates its intrinsic protein 
          kinase activity and results in autophosphorylation of 6 tyrosine 
          residues in the cytoplasmic tail of EGFR.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-177935
    title: SHP2 dephosphorylates Tyr 992 on EGFR
    findings:
      - statement: SHP2 dephosphorylates a RasGAP binding site on EGFR to 
          prevent RasGAP recruitment.
        supporting_text: This inhibition is achieved by the dephosphorylation of
          a RasGAP binding site on the EGF receptor.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-177936
    title: GRB2:SOS1 binds to phosphorylated SHC1 in complex with EGFR
    findings:
      - statement: Phosphorylated SHC1 provides binding sites for the GRB2:SOS1 
          complex.
        supporting_text: The tyrosine sites on SHC1 become possible binding 
          sites for the GRB2:SOS1 complex.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-177937
    title: Phosphorylation of EGFR by SRC kinase
    findings:
      - statement: SRC can tyrosine-phosphorylate EGFR in addition to EGFR 
          autophosphorylation.
        supporting_text: Besides autophosphorylation, EGFR can become 
          tyrosine-phosphorylated by the action of  the proto-oncogene 
          tyrosine-protein kinase, c-src.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-177938
    title: SOS1-mediated nucleotide exchange of RAS (EGF:EGFR:GRB2:SOS1)
    findings:
      - statement: SOS1 interacts with EGFR via GRB2 to activate RAS by GDP-GTP 
          exchange.
        supporting_text: The guanine nucleotide exchange factor SOS1 interacts 
          with EGFR through the adaptor protein, GRB2. Upon formation of this 
          complex, SOS activates RAS by promoting GDP release and GTP binding.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-177939
    title: PI3K converts phosphatidylinositol-4,5-bisphosphate (PIP2) to 
      phosphatidylinositol-3,4,5-trisphosphate (PIP3)
    findings:
      - statement: PI3K phosphorylates PIP2 to form PIP3.
        supporting_text: The kinase activity of PIK3 mediates the 
          phosphorylation of PIP2 to form PIP3
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-177941
    title: GRB2:GAB1 binds to phosphorylated EGFR
    findings:
      - statement: PIK3 regulatory subunit mediates GAB1 association with EGFR, 
          enabling GAB1 phosphorylation.
        supporting_text: The regulatory subunit of PIK3 mediates the association
          of GAB1 and receptor protein-tyrosine kinases such as the  EGF 
          receptor, which can phosphorylate GAB1.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-177942
    title: EGFR binds EGF ligand
    findings:
      - statement: EGF binding to EGFR transmits the signal from the 
          extracellular to cytoplasmic domain.
        supporting_text: EGF binds to the extracellular domain from where the 
          signal is transmitted to the cytoplasmic domain.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-177943
    title: GRB2:SOS1 complex binds to EGF:EGFR complex
    findings:
      - statement: GRB2 binds activated EGFR while in complex with SOS1.
        supporting_text: One such protein, growth factor receptor-bound protein 
          2 (GRB2), can bind activated EGFR with its SH2 domain whilst in 
          complex with SOS through its SH3 domain.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-177944
    title: Activation of SHP2 through the binding to phospho-Gab1
    findings:
      - statement: SHP2 activation occurs when its SH2 domains bind 
          phosphotyrosine proteins to relieve autoinhibition.
        supporting_text: Binding of these domains to phosphotyrosine-containing 
          proteins relieves this autoinhibition, possibly by inducing a 
          conformational change in the enzyme.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-177945
    title: SOS1-mediated nucleotide exchange of RAS (EGF:EGFR:SHC1:GRB2:SOS1)
    findings:
      - statement: SOS1 activates RAS by promoting nucleotide exchange from GDP 
          to GTP.
        supporting_text: SOS1 activates RAS nucleotide exchange from the 
          inactive form (bound to GDP) to an active form (bound to GTP).
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-182969
    title: Phosphorylation of CBL (EGFR:CBL)
    findings:
      - statement: EGF stimulation leads to CBL phosphorylation on Tyr-371, 
          enabling its ubiquitin ligase activity.
        supporting_text: EGF (and indeed FGF, PDGF and NGF) stimulation results 
          in CBL phosphorylation on Tyr-371. Phosphorylation is necessary for 
          CBL to exhibit ubiquitin ligase activity.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-182971
    title: EGFR downregulation
    findings:
      - statement: CBL proteins poly-ubiquitinate activated EGFR, promoting 
          degradation and downregulation.
        supporting_text: The Cbl family of RING-type ubiquitin ligases are able 
          to poly-ubiquitinate EGFR, an essential step in EGFR degradation.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-182986
    title: CBL-mediated ubiquitination of CIN85
    findings:
      - statement: CBL monoubiquitinates CIN85 after EGF stimulation, 
          influencing receptor internalization.
        supporting_text: The adaptor protein CIN85 is monoubiquitinated by CBL 
          after EGF stimulation.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-182990
    title: Sprouty sequesters CBL away from active EGFR
    findings:
      - statement: Sprouty can block CIN85-mediated CBL clustering and thereby 
          reduce EGFR ubiquitination and downregulation.
        supporting_text: This allows Sprouty to block CIN85-mediated clustering 
          of CBL molecules, stablization of CBL-EGFR interactions and efficient 
          ubiquitination and down-regulation of EGFR.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-182993
    title: Ubiquitination of stimulated EGFR (CBL)
    findings:
      - statement: CBL ubiquitinates activated EGFR to drive receptor 
          internalization and degradation.
        supporting_text: CBL down-regulates receptor tyrosine kinases by 
          conjugating ubiquitin to them. This leads to receptor internalization 
          and degradation.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-182994
    title: Assembly of EGFR complex in clathrin-coated vesicles
    findings:
      - statement: The CBL-CIN85-Endophilin complex mediates ligand-induced EGFR
          downregulation.
        supporting_text: CBL-CIN85-Endophilin complex mediates ligand-induced 
          down-regulation of the EGF receptor.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-183002
    title: Beta-Pix:CDC42:GTP binds CBL in EGF:p-6Y-EGFR:CBL:CIN85
    findings:
      - statement: Active CDC42 and Beta-Pix can promote Beta-Pix binding to 
          CBL, displacing CIN85 and potentially blocking CBL clustering.
        supporting_text: High concentrations of active CDC42 (bound to GTP) and 
          Beta-Pix may promote the binding of Beta-Pix to CBL, pushing out the 
          usually preferred binding partner CIN85 (SH3KBP1) from the CBL 
          complex.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-183036
    title: Ubiquitination of stimulated EGFR (CBL:GRB2)
    findings:
      - statement: CBL ubiquitinates activated EGFR, leading to receptor 
          internalization and degradation.
        supporting_text: CBL down-regulates receptor tyrosine kinases by 
          conjugating ubiquitin to them. This leads to receptor internalization 
          and degradation.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-183051
    title: CBL ubiquitinates Sprouty
    findings:
      - statement: EGF stimulation induces Sprouty phosphorylation and 
          CBL-mediated ubiquitination for proteasomal degradation.
        supporting_text: Sprouty is ubiquitinated by CBL in an EGF-dependent 
          manner. EGF stimulation induces the tyrosine phosphorylation of 
          Sprouty, which in turn enhances the interaction of Sprouty with CBL.
  - id: Reactome:R-HSA-183055
    title: Binding of CBL to EGFR
    findings:
      - statement: EGFR phosphorylation at Y1069 (Y1045) creates a docking site
